commentBody: Looks like UNCLE is the new Brian Eno
Touch and go for TAG and Permanent location for SALON were brilliant and made me laugh out loud. A very cute and Tuesday appropriate puzzle.
First

Got the theme really fast - in my first pass with acrosses. Saw it in the NE corner, and was able to get the other circle areas filled in quickly. But.... I reached the revealer and Oregon Trail didn't fit! I was so sure that was what it was going to be!
A perfect Tuesday puzzle.  Very clear theme but not one that's overdone, with clues at the Tuesday level.  Great job, Peter Gorman!

An embankment in a large Oregon city is a Eugene levee.

(These puns make a state-ment.)
Lemon squeezy.

Very clever theme and expertly executed. 

Let’s hear it for the Beaver State!

I'm one of the first for a change.

I don't know what to say, until everyone else has said it.

I thought it was really easy, easier than Mondays.  I think that's something we have to say every Tuesday.

I also chuckled when I got the theme.

I'm glad the inert gases got a call out.  They are often considered lazy and arrogant, because they don't want to have anything to do with the other elements, for the most part.

Personally, I like the noble gases.  Helium can make you sound like a chipmunk, and xenon can make you sound like Barry White.

And I've been a fan of Roger Ebert from his sneak preview days on public TV.  

That's all.  I have to go breath some helium now.

You’re on!  
That is, the people from yesterday who wanted I’M ON instead of I’M IN.
You just had to wait a day.

Had noble instead of inert gases at first. But the crosses didn’t fit. Didn’t we see Eros clued the same way yesterday? I can never remember how to spell blige but fixed it with crosses. 3:45 bettter than my average. Actually watched a live demonstration of Plein-air painting once. Was pretty cool. Enjoyed the Theme

I originally thought the theme would be the OREGON trail, that is until I saw the final theme clue. Very clever and perfectly Tuesday. Seeing AARON BURR makes me think of the Got Milk? commercial from a while back 🤣 https://youtu.be/0Gkqzxss8Ss?si=uK0FiRXYA-C9mbfC
Pored is misspelled. Should be Poured

Our esteemed columnist explained APB as "an urgent message that is typically sent to other members of a particular group, such as a memo sent from one police station to another." Not quite correct; the whole point (ahem) of an APB is that it goes to /all points/ -- i.e., every station gets it and all are asked to watch out for the object of the bulletin. The Amber Alerts are an even more widely diffused APB in which the whole population is enlisted.
The only city I could think of was Portland, but it would only fit as PORTLANDOR or maybe PORTLANDIA. It wasn't until I did a buch of the crosses that I realized it was Bend and had a good CHORTLE.
Cute. Central OR thanks you!
A main course is not by definition an Entree.

An elegantly smooth puzzle, with some of my favorites included: the trustworthy critic; the poignant Shakespearean, almost heroine; and the clever way the whole name of one of my favorite actors was included, like icing on a top of a cake. There were other delicious tidbits as well, which made it all a pleasure to solve.

Thank you, Peter Gorman, for a construction that was tricky and fun.

When I decided to move to Oregon twenty-five years ago, I kept being asked why I was moving to Oregon. "To get oregon-ized," I'd answer. (Unfortunately, I continue to be just good-enough organized.) At first, when I saw OREGON in the NW – and without examining the circles more closely – I thought we might be shooting for scattered states as if the grid were a U.S. map (Maine in the NE?) When the second OREGON revealed itself, I thereafter took advantage of the letters to help along the entries and for a little extra fun. And fun it was. Thank you, Mr. Gorman! (In honor of OPHELIA, here are The Lumineers: https://youtu.be/pTOC_q0NLTk?si=EK-66sTIK0Bz-rOM)
Did a sleepy solve tonight. So sleepy that I kept reading 55A as one word and had to Google it to realize it was two. Goodnight.

This one was pretty smooth for me, with the exception of the CYS/AEGIS crossing.

A couple of years AGO, my imagination might’ve taken me anywhere on that one. But with some hard-earned crossword LOGIC telling me that “and others” usually means the answer ends in S. And with our resident UNCLE @SteveL echoing “Use the cross, Luke” in my mind, I breezed through it without much issue.

Fun, cute, really easy, and with a good theme I didn't fully get until the revealer.  Just about perfect for a Tuesday.  (And much easier than yesterday's weirdness.)

Maybe one of them thar platonic ideals of a Tuesday puzzle, as the cool kids are wont to say...
This was such a clever theme! I too had NOBLEGAS instead of INERTGAS. I also had IKE instead of DDE. Got there in the end without going around the BEND.

My wife and I visited Bend, Oregon in 2013, and we liked both the city and it's surroundings. The theme was quite fun, bending Oregon 🤪.

It's good I knew AEGIS, because I had no idea what CYS might be (by now I had looked it up. To Polish eyes CY is such a strange looking name 😮. Since CY COLEMAN was apparently associated with musical theater [shudder] I've never heard of him). For a moment I doubted myself, and changed AEGIS to AEGId (egida is the Polish spelling of the word, so I thought, what the hell, maybe that's an acceptable variant in English, too), since CYd seemed to make more sense than CYS. However, when I got the "So close" popup, I changed that letter back to an S and got my gold star.

(Nits: To be fair, the *Italian* grilled sandwich is a PANINo, and the American ENTREES for main courses, albeit a gimme, will always continue to surprise me)

I'm going for a short trip with my father so I might not post for a day or two.
"Panini" is plural. A single sandwich is a "panino".
Very nice fill.
Fun! I saw the pattern in the circles and got all of them before figuring out the hint clue, at which point I mentally slapped my forehead because I’ve been to Bend.

Final change was from TAS to RAS fixing a rather amusing mount TUSHMORE 

Maybe if they insist on adding a fifth it can be their …

Nice puzzle. I’d like to see Bend but it’ll have to wait until 2029.

A grilled Italian sandwich is a panino. 

Multiple grilled Italian sandwiches are panini.
I’ve somehow gone my whole life without seeing “ECONO” used as shorthand. My problem, not the constructor’s; this was a fun and relatively breezy solve.
I was wondering what a PADLEG was until I got the BOP
I think it's important to note that BOP has not meant what is clued here for a couple years. It's now widely used to refer to something certainly too vulgar to write here.

I actually found this a little more difficult than the average Tuesday. Definitely doable, no lookups required, but it had enough chew to be engaging. I’ve never been to Bend, Oregon, but it appears to be full of twists and turns. Maybe someday I’ll have the flexibility to visit.

Entrees always throws me. An Entree in Oz is a starter dish, not a main course

Also what am I missing with Uncle? I got it from the crosses

Once I got the theme it was a fun little fill
Clever theme resulting with a fun solve, and yes, Peter I did enjoy the solve.
That was pretty clever and a fun solve.

Fun puzzle and an impressive piece of construction. After my first pass I focused on working out the reveal and then just had a good time working that in to all the circled squares. Kind of appropriate puzzle find today. Turns out that NORSEGODS was an answer in only one other puzzle - a Wednesday from September 2, 2015 by Kevin Christian and Brad Wilbur. And... it was the reveal, clued as... "They're hidden in 17-, 25-, 36- and 47-Across" And those answers were: PANTYRAID MOODINDIGO TRUTHORDARE HELLOKITTY Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/2/2015&g=58&d=A ....
Halfway through, I was hoping for OREGON TRAIL as the revealer. Alas, no.

I'm from Oregon! 🙂

(Just needed to say that!)

Saw the OREGONs very early and knew the city. Still took me almost ten minutes to finish. Not sure why---no real stumpers for me in the grid. 

Nice puzzle to start what will be a very hot Tuesday here.
Tony Jacklin?

This is a beautiful grid build.  The answer set is remarkably smooth, considering the seven OREGONs plus a ten-letter revealer, which greatly constrict the answer possibilities.

Adding to the constriction is that the OREGONs are all in a specific order.  That is, starting with one of the O’s, you can spell OREGON without having to skip a square.  Thus, you can have

ORE
NOG
as in the lower middle of the grid, but you can’t have, say,

REO
GON
because in going from OREG to ON, you’d have to make a jump.  If the circles had been allowed to simply be anagrams of OREGON in any order, the grid would have been easier to fill.

And, somehow, on top of all this, Peter was able to splash beauty into the grid, with OPHELIA, AGOG, DIABLO, PRIM, AEGIS, and IRONY.

Plus, for me, a pair of bonuses.  There was a TIL that “chortle” is a combo of “chuckle” and “snort”.  Hah!  Plus, there was the lovely PuzzPair© of GOGO and RUSHMORE.

A nod of respect for your skill, Peter, not to mention gratitude for the fun solve and extras.  Bravo!

Ye gods! I don't even have to read the comments to hear the shouts from the chemists, and Italian restaurateurs*! 

By curious coincidence, at dinner yesterday evening at our neighbors, I was served a lager, from Costco (Kirkland Signature), which, in fine print, I found was brewed in Bend, Oregon. It was quite good. (Not a paid advertisement.)

Four faces aren't enough, dontcha think?

*a suggested clue: [A sandwich, or two in Italy]

(Enough neutral characters typed to now allow me to say I found this a fill-heavy, unsatisfying puzzle.)

Smooth solve, nice open grid. Would have loved to see LOREN play OPHELIA, but alas there’s no record that she ever attempted Shakespeare.  Great clues for RUSHMORE and SALON. Theme was cute (if a bit random).
A chortle is not a chuckle plus a snort. What a strange clue.
Ahh, the perennial panini/panino thing. Never gets old...

One Italian sandwich = panino.

More than one Italian sandwich = panini.
Panini is plural, like octopi . . . How much longer will you continue to perpetuate these errors?

Funny and unexpected reveler.  Nice puzzle, Peter!

I love seeing the chain yanking PANINI, and all of the outrage it generates.  Maybe the NYT is trying to drive up traffic.

Enjoyable puzzle, it just made me think about themes sometimes - this seems like a really difficult one for the constructor, but not in any way for the solver. I used the theme once to help identify that argon and neon aren't "noble" gases since the B didn't fit, but apart from that everything just went ini with the fill and I finished way under average.
There's the appreciation of a puzzle as a piece of art: the intelligence and effort of the work; there's also the appreciation of a puzzle as a hobby: how it interacts with solvers and leads us on a journey of revelation. I feel this failed on the second criterion, although I feel churlish for saying it...

Like others here, I expected an Oregon Trail revealer, but i was so pleasantly surprised to see BEND. It’s such a beautiful town in a gorgeous region—I haven’t been there in years, but every time I get a Deschutes’ beers (which is every time I see one on offer), I’m flooded with pleasant memories. 

Also, I really enjoyed this puzzle! The bright fill and bent OREGONs made for a quick, fun solve. Thanks, Peter Gorman & ed’s.
This one was a fun, breezy one. I did get a little annoyed at 44 across though. The clue should have been “Grilled Italian SandwichES.” The solution is plural after all!

Wow, a lot of people are upset about PANINI. I have literally always seen PANINI used to mean a single sandwich. I don't even know what the singular form would be--panin? Wikipedia tells me it's panino, a word I have never seen in my life, and I have eaten a lot of sandwiches. It also says panino is not a common word.

Guys, it's a PANINI.

Panino/ panini:
Just clue it "sandwiches".  It's more correct, no big deal.
Cute solve for a Tuesday. Thanks, Peter Gorman!
Who is Ben Doregon? 🤪

PANINI definition: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/panini https://www.collinsdictionary.com/us/dictionary/english/panini https://www.dictionary.com/browse/panini https://dictionary.cambridge.org/us/dictionary/english/panini https://www.thefreedictionary.com/Panini https://www.oxfordlearnersdictionaries.com/us/definition/english/panini https://www.yourdictionary.com/panini Now will all the pseudopedants please stifle yourselves and go have a nice panini. Or a tamale. Or some octopi. Unless, of course, "the dictionary is wrong." Language. Evolves. Sic transit gloria panini.

What do folks call themselves up there?  OREGANOS?  OREGONDERS?  ORE-GONERS?  OREGONIANS?  OREGONSERS?

A lot of folks were exiting the State of California and moving to OREGON--especially BEND!-- as the real estate got ever pricier, and that was before it got really crazy.  (We left in 1987, feeling we had done well in selling our 180K house for 280K; it last sold for 2.6 million.)  

This concludes the snippet of history for today.  I have more quilting to do; closing in on completion.

Regarding a number of comments today: 

tomato / tomahto
potato / potahto

Let's call the whole thing off. 

...

What silly kook out there 
felt chuffed for remembering that
Patrick Harris spells his name
NEaL?

And then had to flyspeck to get the gold star?

Not this gal!
Nope. Definitely not me.

Silly rabbits.
Whatever happened to “I done did this puzz” guy? I think about him sometimes.
Panini is the plural of panino.

Oh, and another late puzzle find. A Sunday from August 11, 2013 by Dan Schoenholz with the title "Added Satisfaction." A couple of clue answer examples: Where most things rank in importance to a Muslim? : AFTERALLAH Webster's directive to the overly formal? : JUSTSAYNOAH Equipment list for a hashish-smoking fisherman? : HOOKAHLINEANDSINKER And a couple of other theme answers: AUNTIEAHEM HEADTOTAHOE Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/11/2013&g=102&d=A ...

If Americans pronounce bruschetta as "brooshetta," (and too many do), why be surprised about "panini"?  It ain't like anybody provides usage lessons for words taken from other languages.  

In the film, "Nonnas," Bruno asks Joe, "capish?" (never mind the correct Italian spelling, much less the pronunciation) and Joe, rather than answering the correct, "capisco," says, "capish."  So, yeah, panini, brooshetta, EYEtalian.
It's panino. Two of the sandwiches are panini.
I take issue with the clue for 37A. While the overall face of the mountain as it is usually viewed faces southeast, our first president is facing south and our 16th is for sure facing southwest.

I am enjoying all you from "Vinca" Italy (I had Vinca!) and your thoughts about panini/ panino! EYEtalian, from NJ etc. It comes to mind what I once learned (not TIL but OIL?) on that well-loved, long-gone acrostic: graffito! who knew? Buona giornata

Remember when DOGE was a cute mis-spelling of "dog" in an internet meme? Now it has taken over everything!

(The correct plural is dogi.)
Thanks for a clever and fun puzzle
Smooth solve, no contortions needed.  Nicely done and thanks.

I never received a Games newsletter yesterday and I have not received one today -- yet. 

And my way of getting to the MIDI does not work today -- altering the date. Maybe they've caught on and want to foil this method of gaining entry. Bastids! 

So, has anyone else received the newsletter? If so, is there a new link to the MIDI that you might share? Thanks!



Also: I don't think anyone has mentioned that PANINI is wrong yet...  😎

i am EXTREMELY relieved that 7D has nothing to do with that pseudo US government department with the same letters that is destroying our country.
337 people out of about 1500 in just one division of HHS retired or were fired last week.
44A I’m nitpicking here, but one “grilled Italian sandwich” is a PANINO.  Multiple sandwiches are PANINI.

BTW, the title of the puzzle, Think Out Loud is a nod to Dave Miller's noon M-F talk show on Oregon Public Broadcasting. Miller is an Oregon treasure. His show involves all things Oregon, from all parts of Oregon. 

It is the kind of show that includes everybody. And discusses everything. He is respected by everyone.

A generalist, his interview style is friendly, probing, and inciteful. 

Everyone should hope to have someone like Miller in their state doing a radio show like his.
Fun one!

What a lovely Tuesday grid, Peter Gorman! Once I fixed my immediate entry of "Ike" to DDE, it was pretty smooth sailing for me. I loved seeing the "Bends" for Oregon. I also enjoyed seeing the city of Bend be highlighted rather than Portland (OR) which my hometown on the east coast is sometimes mistaken for by well meaning, west coast-inclined assumptions!

Good puzzle.  Zipped through without too much trouble, but did not get the "jingle" that it was completed correctly.  My error was using "IKE" for JFKs predecessor.  Led to a couple of other short errors, but had entered words that seemed to fit.
Now this is a brilliant puzzle. Inspired, outside-the-box theme idea executed cleverly with some sparkling fill and an a-ha revealer. Spectacular Tuesday. 3:28.

A lovely crossword today. 
My unknown names(the actors)  were solved by the crossers, I looked up DOGE coin,  and I am only left wondering - 
Meaning of zingers/JABS?
NOG? Can't figure out the clue or the solution.
Thank you.
spot on!!! may every day play this way be it easy or not.. this was easy

The Mt Rushmore four faces don't all face southeast. If they did, you could tell by all their noses pointing in the same direction. Roosevelt and Lincoln are almost 90 degrees apart by my reckoning.  He should have worded the clue differently if he meant the faces as a group face southeast.
Although I solved this in 2 minutes below average time nevertheless I found it really smart for a Tuesday! I love how the constructor quote at Einstein on the leap from LOGIC to imagination.

14A. The clue [Permanent location?] refers not to a building or other structure

At first I thought it would be GRAVE.  :(

ICANSO?

I'm lost on that one.

Another late puzzle find. Never seen another one like this either. A Thursday from November 7, 2013 by Alan DerKazarian. Each theme answer was clued straightforwardly but the answers started with one or more rebus squares. I'll put those rebuses in parentheses. (and I'll leave out the clues - see if you can figure them out). (ARMED)BANDITS (BIT)(BIT)CROOKS (CARD)(CARD)(CARD)MONTE (WAY)(WAY)(WAY)(WAY)STOP Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/7/2013 ...

re: earlier comments 
on mount TUSHmore
a few more CRACKS:

rather than a mountain
it would be better on a BUTTE...

and not require one to ASCEND as far...

and since they would not charge ASCENT
it would be well worth a PEAK
even you had to stand in the
BOTTOM line for hours...

one wonders how many times
the sculptor of such an
UNDER taking might have to
remind his subjects to...

BEND O'ER AGAIN!

44 Across, "grilled Italian sandwich" is singular (one sandwich)

"Panini" is plural.  A grilled Italian sandwich is "panino"
If you give a mouse a sandwich . . . https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=garNxavx8gY
Had a wonderful trip to Bend a few years ago with a group of friends. Fantastic microbreweries and restaurants, plus the joy of visiting the last remaining Blockbuster in the world!
A fun puzzle to be solving from my hometown of Bend, a treasure of the west. Bendite puzzlers, sound off!

Well, I had a lot of fun with this, but didn’t find it quite as fast or as easy as some of you did. I saw what was happening with the circles fairly early and also got the revealer early (sometimes I hop all over the grid when I solve).
I did about half the puzzle before my daily 5 mile walk and then came back to it while eating lunch. I was also a little bummed by 7D but not as bothered by PANINI as many of you were. Language and usage are always changing.
Thanks for a really enjoyable Tuesday puzzle, Peter Gorman.
I was sure the revealer was gonna be the Oregon trail, took me a while to figure it out. It was super fun.

7/29 
41 across should be grilled Italian SANDWICHES, because panini is plural.

If you cut a panino into two pieces, is it now a panini?

If you do the cutting in a forest, with nobody around, was it really cut?

(Sam)which came first?  The panino or the panini?

And why isn't it panina and panine?  Patriarchy?

Question, question, questioni.  Humans have three questioni.

For 66A I first entered Italy, but that fell apart quickly. Then I'm thinking, how the hell am I supposed to know the dumb town where he's from?? Oh it's VINCI, ok then, whatever. 

Came here and *then* realized that it's a great clue. LOL. Especially for a Tuesday.

I spent today in Italy! Huge advantage to living where I do, it's a super easy trip to Italy for lunch. The Ligurian coast is a treasure.
Man, wait until all these pedants find out my singular (in every way) dog is named Cannoli.
I found this fun and just chewy enough to make it an excellent Tuesday! Thanks Mr. Gorman.

When I first started to figure out the theme of the puzzle, I worried I was going to die of dysentery. 

I was really relieved that it only led me to BENDOREGON.

Phew!
Very fun and creative puzzle… oh and PANINI is plural

When I saw PANINI in the puzzle, I knew today would not be a good day do a shot each time the same puzzle nit came up...

With my inclusion of it here, I'd be 64 shots in!!  (And another 28 if I include PANINo. Yikes!! 

But you know, there are so few things in life we can really count on. It's sort of reassuring that perennial prodigious panini pandemonium will always be a surety in this comment section.
I got the theme RIGHT AWAY! (Note my hometown 😁)

anyone else having trouble opening the midi today? i've been doing the thing where i just change the date in the url, and that's been working. but today i keep getting an error message.

help?

I am starting to think I glitched the matrix. I go on a business trip to Oregon and I get this themed puzzle to work on in my hotel room. Having Oregon on the brain already made this a very quick solve. Only trip up was having IKE instead of DDE for awhile.
Einstein never said this, of course. Although the internet seems insistent that he did... along with a ton of other sophomoric quotes.

Way better than emus eating oreos while Ali shouts Ole! under the ell near the apse outside Eden....
@salty in or third 😉

@Rebecca

@Mike

This pun is Best in Show.

@Francis "I'm glad the inert gases got a call out.  They are often considered lazy and arrogant, because they don't want to have anything to do with the other elements, for the most part."

I feel sorry for the column 18 gases: the way they are bullied by heartless chemists into forming compounds, even if they don't want to, purely to satisfy the chemists' egos. (I feel the same way about the trans-uranian elements; which means, I guess, those six atoms of Organesson got a double whammy.)

@Bill

😂😂😂  Yeah, the noble gases get no respect.  No respect.

@Megan Not sure about zeros, but there have been a lot of repeat answers the last few days. I recall seeing:

ASAMI
RIGID
IMON

Multiple times recently.
@Steve definitely a lot of repeats lately
@Megan Never confuse Blige with bilge! Ask me how I know! Arrgh!
@Captain Kidnap not confusing the placement of the L. I always want to spell it Blyghe
@Cherry hilarious! I don’t remember seeing that one before today. Thanks for sharing 😁
@Alex Not in this case. Pore over means to study closely or examine. Pour over means to make coffee. You need both to pull an all-nighter before the big test.

@SBK
I remember the difference by thinking of 'poring over a book' as looking into the very pores.

PORE the verb has a different etymology than PORE the noun. But both of them are long fixed in the language; the verb, from the 13th century; the noun, from the 12th. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/pore
@SBK police stations are the particular group?

@Spmm.  Unless you happen to live in America. 
I know that I have the same reaction every time.

@Dana D In the long and storied parade of ships that have sailed, that is one of them. https://www.goodhousekeeping.com/appliances/g64458504/best-panini-press/ As they say, a hero ain't nothing but a sandwich.

@B

A PANINo is an Italian sandwich, a PANINI is an Italian-style sandwich everywhere outside Italy. Of course today's clue is acceptable in crosswordese shorthand, but it begs for nits to be picked.
@Spmm seemingly everywhere, except the US. 🤷🏻‍♂️ https://www.casaschools.com/blog/why-americans-say-entree-for-main-course/

@Spmm

G'day, mate.  Or, should I say, g'night, since it's morning in America, so it must be nighttime in Oz.

In the US, a "mate," BTW, is a husband or wife, or at least a longtime significant other.  It's not a pal or a buddy.

As the article Paul linked indicates, the original ENTREE was neither a starter/appetizer (as they say by you) nor a main dish (as they say here), but rather a course that was served between the two, which no longer exists in most places.  Rather than ditching the word in both places, Anglophones decided to reassign the French word to another course, because, well, it's French.  Unfortunately, they assigned it to different courses.

I suggest that at this point, we table the discussion for later, and everyone who is complaining have a tamale.

@B

The long and storied parade of ships that have sailed would more than fill up Fleet Week.

@Steve L

Or a taco, because it's Tuesday.

@sotto voce Nice. My first thought was Ophelia’s verse in Dylan’s Desolation Row: “ Ophelia, she's 'neath the window for her I feel so afraid On her twenty-second birthday she already is an old maid To her, death is quite romantic she wears an iron vest Her profession's her religion, her sin is her lifelessness And though her eyes are fixed upon Noah's great rainbow She spends her time peeking into Desolation Row.” https://www.dailymotion.com/video/x2zbys3

@Warren

For me it starts with Desolation and skips to Watchtower.
But I'll find the MTV unplugged of Desolation on YouTube.
Thank you so much!

@Steve L

All right!

@Striker

Funny you should call me UNCLE.  In our family, our two adult children and our adult niece and nephew, and all of their spouses (and our grandniece) often get together for visits.  In referring to me in group texts and large-group conversations as "Uncle Daddy".  (I call her "Aunt Mommy," too.)
@Steve L I worked with a man who had an Uncle Dad, but that was the result of a wee bit of infidelity.

@Steve L

I imagine the Ls having some wonderful and lively family gatherings. At the next one be sure and tell them all that Striker says hello. 👍

@Andrzej

I think B is played five-dimensional chess.

@Francis

I took that as an intentionally Viennese accented psychological analysis.

@Francis

Emus ate my question about what you *do* enjoy exposing. It may have featured an aubergine emoji.

@Lisa Marshall

Just so you don't make the IKE mistake ever again...

JFK was a signal that initials were needed.  IKE has never been clued to another president's initials, although he has been clued to his own initials several times (mostly pre-Shortz).  (The latter is valid because it's an equivalency.)

But DDE has been clued to JFK (predecessor), HST (successor), RMN (running mate/boss), other abbreviations like POTUS, WWII, etc., and "inits." or "monogram".

Hope this helps!

@Andrzej

Honestly "Cy" looks like a pretty weird name to me too.  I suppose it's short for Cyrus.  "Syd" is a similar strange abbreviation....

@B

Sydney?

@Francis

Body of gangster Cy Panini unlikely to be found. 'Frankie "the Chemist" likes his acid,' police say.

@Andrzej

My late brother-in-law was a Seymour, always known as Sy. Maybe the “C” was used because  it works better with Coleman? 🤷🏼‍♀️ (BIL had a surname beginning in “S”.)
@Andrzej  I assume that, at least in most cases, Cy is the short for Cyrus. I don't know if anyone called Cyrus Vance "Cy," though. Seems doubtful.

@Andrzej

Seymour was a fairly common 2nd generation Jewish name, though I have no idea why, and Sy has always been the main accepted diminutive form. I think he chose Cy simply because it was less identifiable as Jewish, as was Coleman.

@Times Rita @ Darcy O'D @ HEK

Thank you for your ideas 🙂. Times Rita's sounds most plausible, I think.

@HEK

Cyrus Vance, Jr., the former NY County DA, is called Cy.  

Often, it's a nickname for Seymour, although then it's sometimes spelled Sy.

The early baseball pitcher, Cy Young, of the eponymous annual award for pitching excellence, was actually named Denton.  His nickname was derived from "cyclone," a description of his pitching.

@Francis

And don't forget the occasional Fran, as in the quarterback Fran Tarkenton, which seems like a rather girlie nickname, but I wouldn't tell him that to his face.
@Andrzej Have a great time Andrzej. We'll be here when you get back.

@JD

I bet I will! We will be visiting Mazowsze Północne (Northern Mazovia), the region where my father was born and grew up before moving to Warsaw to pursue his career. It's not very tourist-y, but there are quite a few interesting historical monuments: Gothic churches (built in very late, austere, Mazovian Gothic, in the 16th century), castles, and palaces, all set in a rural, mostly flat landscape dotted with prosperous villages thriving on good soil. We will be eating traditional Polish food, but maybe I won't die if I forget about cholesterol levels for two days :D

I've never really understood how Roosevelt (Theodore) fits with the others.  Not that I don't like him, but compared to Washington and Lincoln...

I used to think a lot more of Jefferson before I read the Meacham biography.

@Heidi

😂😂😂😂😂😂

Brilliant!

I knew they're be a Teddy supporter out there that would really make the case!

And you did it hilariously and I have to say convincingly!

Long live the legacy of TR!

@Francis

Bully! 😁 If you’ve never read a biography of TR, I highly recommend it. He had a fascinating life. He had a thirst for adventure that led him to climb the Matterhorn and navigate an uncharted part of the Amazon (an expedition that he barely survived). He loved animals and had a menagerie in the White House, including miniature ponies, a pet badger, and an actual bear. He was the first American to win the Nobel Peace Prize. A lengthy campaign speech helped to save his life when a would-be assassin’s bullet was caught in the thick text. (And yes, he continued to give the speech.) He created Yellowstone National Park after a camping trip with John Muir. And so much more! 😃

@Heidi

Actually, now that you mention it, I do recall almost all the events you list here.  They were hidden in my mind until you mentioned them. 

I was especially enamored of how he struggled to overcome an poor health in childhood.  The resilience of the man was astonishing.

I'm also fond of a story, probably apocryphal, about how his daughter Alice was a terror.  A White House visitor asked why he didn't control that child.  He responded that he could either run the country, or control Alice.  He couldn't possibly do both.

Nevertheless, I think I would have loathed actually experiencing the man.  My sense is that he had a very high opinion of himself, but that doesn't lead to cordiality even though he was right.  The rupture of his party led to Woodrow "I-really-loved-Birth-of-a-Nation" Wilson.  

Stunningly, at the time, I, knowing the American history I now know, would have hated the Wilson presidency.

@Francis
Theodore (Teddy, to me) was the first president to address conservation (national parks!) and preservation of wilderness areas.  He also instituted reforms (after he read _The Jungle_ especially!) and addressed the issue of trusts.  A fairly fascinating man, really.

@Heidi
Tsk ....if I had read on down the list, I could have spared myself some effort, but I am glad we feel the same way about that president!
